article_title: Mosque-based med clinic has growing impact
article_text: To continue reading this story, you will need to be a digital subscriber to ExpressNews.com.

article_metadata.description: Given the absence of prominent religious iconography, you might not know that the adjacent Muslim Children Education and Civic Center, which runs a major local mosque, leases the property — or that the operation itself even exists.  The concept is to fill in the gap ... between people who have their own health insurance and those covered by the (Affordable Care Act).  While not a walk-in clinic at this point due to its limited capacity, the center does offer chronic disease management with limited primary care for a handful of regular patients.  The clinic takes appointments from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m. Sundays and offers other programs like in-home, “ask-a-doc” screenings, a mobile mammography unit and a series of major health fairs every six months.  Haq said the center's long-term goal is to add another day to the clinic's operating hours, as well as a mobile clinic to help respond to displaced victims of disasters like hurricanes and flooding in the Gulf Coast who are evacuated to San Antonio and South Texas.  According to San Antonio's Center for Refugee Services, several thousand refugees live in San Antonio, many hailing from Islamic areas like Iraq and Iran, with large groups of others from Nepal, Bosnia and other parts of Europe, Africa and Asia.  Most of his patients there come in without health insurance and aren't eligible for Medicaid or Medicare, and several deal with expensive, chronic issues like diabetes or heart problems.
article_metadata.author.name: By Jeremy T. Gerlach, San Antonio Express-News
